revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Thomas Dudley Cabot | image = ThomasDudleyCabot.jpg | caption = | birth_date = May 1, 1897 | birth_place = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], U.S.{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/1995/cabot-0621.html|title=Senior trustee, Thomas D. Cabot, dies at 98|publisher=[[MIT News]]|date=June 21, 1995|accessdate=July 26, 2011}} | death_date = June 8, 1995 (age 98) | death_place = [[Weston, Massachusetts]], U.S.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/10/obituaries/thomas-cabot-98-capitalist-and-philanthropist-is-dead.html?src=pm|title=Thomas Cabot, 98, Capitalist And Philanthropist, Is Dead|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=June 10, 1995|accessdate=July 26, 2011}} | education = [[Buckingham Browne & Nichols]] (1913)
[[Harvard University]] ([[Scientiæ Baccalaureus|S.B.]] [[Engineering]], 1919) | occupation = [[Businessman]], [[philanthropist]] | spouse = Virginia Wellington Cabot (m. 1920-his death in 1995) | children = Louis Wellington Cabot
Thomas Dudley Cabot Jr.
Robert Moors Cabot
Edmund Billings Cabot
Linda Cabot Black{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/29/style/linda-black-is-married.html?src=pm|title=Linda Black Is Married|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=July 30, 2011|date=January 29, 1989}} | parents = [[Godfrey Lowell Cabot]]
Maria Moors Cabot}} '''Thomas Dudley Cabot''' (May 1, 1897 – June 8, 1995) was an American businessman and philanthropist. He also became [[U.S. Department of State]]'s Director of Office of International Security Affairs.{{cite web|url=http://www.trumanlibrary.org/oralhist/cabottd.htm|first=Richard D.|last=McKinzie|title=Oral History Interview with Thomas D. Cabot: Director, Office of International Security Affairs, Department of State, 1951; consultant, Special Mission to Egypt, 1953.|publisher=[[Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum]]|date=June 6, 1975|accessdate=September 19, 2011}} ==Early life== Cabot was born in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. His father was [[Godfrey Lowell Cabot]], founder of [[Cabot Corporation]]{{cite web|url=http://www.cabot-corp.com/About-Cabot/History|title=The History of Cabot Corporation|publisher=[[Cabot Corporation]]|accessdate=July 26, 2011}} and a philanthropist. His mother was Maria Moors Cabot. Cabot was named after [[Thomas Dudley]], governor of [[Massachusetts Bay Colony]] who signed the charter creating [[Harvard College]].{{cite web|url=http://dudleyundergrad.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k71131&pageid=icb.page346418|title=Dudley House History|publisher=[[Harvard College]], Dudley House Undergraduate Office|accessdate=July 26, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109164257/http://dudleyundergrad.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k71131&pageid=icb.page346418|archivedate=November 9, 2016|df=}} Two of his siblings were [[John Moors Cabot]] (b. 1901), [[U.S. Ambassador]] to [[Sweden]], [[Colombia]], [[Brazil]], and [[Poland]] during the [[Eisenhower administration|Eisenhower]] and [[Kennedy administration]],{{cite web|url=http://eisenhower.archives.gov/Research/Finding_Aids/C.html|title=The Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum Finding Aids: C|publisher=[[Dwight D. Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum]]|accessdate=July 28, 2011}} and Eleanor Cabot of the [[Eleanor Cabot Bradley Estate]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zAZUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA8&lpg=RA2-PA8&dq=Cabot+bradley#v=onepage&q=cabot%20bradley&f=false|title=Town & Country, Volumes 75-76|work=[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]]|date=February 20, 1919|accessdate=July 28, 2011}} Cabot graduated from [[Buckingham Browne & Nichols|Browne & Nichols School]] in 1913.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbns.org/supporting-bbn/giving-programs/endowment-capital|title=Giving Programs: Endowment & Spendable Funds|publisher=[[Buckingham Browne & Nichols]]|accessdate=July 26, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005181200/http://www.bbns.org/supporting-bbn/giving-programs/endowment-capital|archivedate=October 5, 2011|df=}} He took some courses at Boston Tech (now known as [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]) and [[Curtiss Flying School]],{{cite web|first=Carol|last=Losos|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1985/4/25/cabot-19-recalls-free-flying-days/|title=Cabot '19 Recalls Free Flying Days|publisher=[[Harvard Crimson]]|date=April 25, 1985|accessdate=July 26, 2011}} becoming a [[World War I]] flight instructor at [[Kelly Field Annex|Kelly Field]] in the [[U.S. Army Signal Corps#World War I|U.S. Army Signal Corps]],{{cite web|first=|last=|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1995/6/24/former-overseer-haa-head-cabot-dies/|title=Former Overseer, HAA Head Cabot Dies at 98|publisher=[[Harvard Crimson]]|date=June 24, 1995|accessdate=July 26, 2011}} before graduating cum laude from [[Harvard University]] with a [[Scientiæ Baccalaureus|S.B.]] in [[Engineering]], in 1919. ==Career== Upon graduation, Cabot started working for [[Cabot Corporation]], founded by his father. He served as CEO of Cabot Corporation from 1922 to 1960, when he relinquished active control of the company, and went to his Boston office as Director [[Emeritus]] on a regular basis until his death. Cabot was also a longtime director of [[United Fruit Company]], and became its president in 1948 in hopes of reformation, but resigned in 1949. His brother John Moors Cabot was a major shareholder of United Fruit,{{cite web|url=http://hum.uchicago.edu/~jagoldsm/Papers/JFK/3_IntelligenceCommunity.pdf|first=John|last=Goldsmith|title=Course on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy, Chapter 3: Intelligence Community to 1963, Vietnam|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|accessdate=September 18, 2011}} as was another family member, [[Henry Cabot Lodge, Jr.]],{{cite web|url=http://www.library.spscc.ctc.edu/electronicreserve/swanson/SilenciodeNetoimdbnotesFall2003.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402142914/http://www.library.spscc.ctc.edu/electronicreserve/swanson/SilenciodeNetoimdbnotesFall2003.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=April 2, 2012|first=|last=|title=Silencio de Neto, El (1994)|publisher=[[South Puget Sound Community College]]|accessdate=September 18, 2011}} who also served as a director of United Fruit.{{cite web|url=http://www.utexas.edu/conferences/africa/ads/879.html|first=Brian|last=Mitchell|title=No. 879: G8 AND LIVE8 - GLOBAL POWER AND POLITICAL NAIVETY|publisher=[[University of Texas at Austin]]|accessdate=September 18, 2011}} In 1951, Cabot served as [[U.S. Department of State]]'s Director of Office of International Security Affairs during the [[Truman administration]], where he spoke for the State Department on [[NATO]] affairs, was in charge of a U.S. program arming allies throughout the world, and supervised the disbursement of $6 billion in [[United States foreign aid|foreign economic]] and [[United States military aid|military aid]]. In 1953, he also served as consultant on a special development mission in [[Egypt]]. In 1960, a [[Central Intelligence Agency]] cover{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,877512-1,00.html|first=|last=|title=HONDURAS: Swans, Spooks and Boobies|publisher=[[TIME Magazine]]|date=December 6, 1961|accessdate=September 18, 2011}} called Gibraltar Steamship Company (which didn't own any steamships and whose president was Cabot){{cite web|url=http://pl703.pairlitesite.com/Stations/Swan.pdf|first=Tom|last=Kneitel|title=Inside the CIA's Secret Radio Paradise: Part I|publisher=[[Popular Communications]]|date=November 1985|accessdate=September 18, 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=37LopzbPotYC&pg=PA608&lpg=PA608&dq=gibraltar+steamship+president&source=bl&ots=vrCFnTECFv&sig=E7EdhnB8RFjTtjDg74KhFKKPoT0&hl=en&ei=A_h1TsSUOdLK0AHszsXIDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=gibraltar%20steamship%20president&f=false|title=That Infernal Little Cuban Republic: The United States and The Cuban Revolution|first=Lars|last=Schoultz|publisher=[[University of North Carolina Press]]|year=2009|accessdate=September 18, 2011}} Pg. 608 owned and established [[Radio Swan]] on [[Swan Islands, Honduras|Swan Island]], a covert black operation to win supporters for U.S. policies and discredit [[Fidel Castro]]. Cabot,{{cite web|url=http://www.mega.nu/ampp/roundtable/CFRA-Elist.html|title=Council on Foreign Relations Membership List (A-E)|publisher=mega.nu|accessdate=October 8, 2011}} his brother John Moors Cabot,{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} another family member Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.,{{cite web|url=http://www.mega.nu/ampp/roundtable/CFRL-Rlist.html|title=Council on Foreign Relations Membership List (L-R)|publisher=mega.nu|accessdate=October 8, 2011}} and Cabot's son, Louis Wellington Cabot, were all [[Council on Foreign Relations]] members inducted in 1992. ===Philanthropic work=== Cabot also served on the [[Harvard Board of Overseers]], was a Director of the Harvard Alumni Association and significant benefactor of the university, and recipient of a Harvard Medal and honorary Doctor of Laws degree in 1970. In 1985, Harvard's [[Cabot House]] was named in honor of Cabot and his wife.{{cite web|url=http://cabot.harvard.edu/history/|title=Cabot House History|publisher=[[Cabot House]]|accessdate=July 26, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719205225/http://cabot.harvard.edu/history/|archivedate=July 19, 2011|df=}} The Cabot Science Complex is also named in their honor. ===Writings=== * ''Quick-Water and Smooth: A Canoeist's Guide to New England Rivers'', 1935 * ''Beggar on Horseback: The Autobiography of Thomas D. Cabot'', 1979 * ''Avelinda: The Legacy of a Yankee Yachtsman'', 1991 ==Personal life== Cabot was married to Virginia Wellington Cabot for 75 years, from 1920 to his death in 1995. They resided in [[Weston, Massachusetts]] for seventy-five years, and had five children: Louis Wellington Cabot, businessman, philanthropist, former Chairman of [[Federal Reserve Bank of Boston]],{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/style/mabel-brandon-and-louis-cabot.html|title=Mabel Brandon and Louis Cabot|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=July 30, 2011|date=June 1, 1997}} Thomas Dudley Cabot Jr., Robert Moors Cabot, Dr. Edmund Billings Cabot, [[Phillips Academy|Andover]] star and retired surgeon,{{cite web|url=http://heritage.noblenet.org/items/show/16187|title=Andover Class of 1961 Edmund Billings Cabot's Formal Portrait|publisher=NOBLE Digital Heritage|accessdate=July 30, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328092541/http://heritage.noblenet.org/items/show/16187|archive-date=2012-03-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://sailorsforthesea.org/about-sailors-for-the-sea/board-of-directors/edmund-b-cabot.aspx|title=Board of Directors: EDMUND B. CABOT, MD, FACS|publisher=Sailors for the Sea|accessdate=July 30, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314082121/http://sailorsforthesea.org/about-sailors-for-the-sea/board-of-directors/edmund-b-cabot.aspx|archivedate=March 14, 2012|df=}} and Linda Cabot Black, cofounder of [[Opera Company of Boston]] and Opera New England. in his 80's he lost the sight of an eye in a cross-country skiing accident, but he retained his enthusiasm for the active life. He and his wife, who celebrated their 75th wedding anniversary were tramping the mountains of Colorado. They also had 29 grandchildren, and 23 great-grandchildren. Virginia Cabot died in 1997 at Phillips House in Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She was 97. == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cabot, Thomas Dudley}} [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:Cabot family]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Cambridge, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences alumni]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:American people of World War I]] [[Category:People from Weston, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Buckingham Browne & Nichols School alumni]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 10 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
A '''travel survey''' (or '''travel diary''' or '''travel behavior inventory''') is a survey of individual [[travel behavior]]. Most surveys collect information about an individual (socio-economic, demographic, etc.), their household (size, structure, relationships), and a diary of their journeys on a given day (their start and end location, start and end time, mode of travel, accompaniment and purpose of travel).
Major travel surveys are conducted in metropolitan areas typically once a decade. Some regions, notably metropolitan [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]] conduct a panel survey, which interviews the same people year after year, to see how their particular behavior evolves over time.
==Recent or continuous city-wide travel surveys== [[Auckland]], New Zealand - A travel survey was conducted in 2006 and involved 6,000 households in the greater Auckland region.<ref>[http://www.tuti.com.au/AHTS06.html Auckland Travel Survey] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106043049/http://www.tuti.com.au/AHTS06.html |date=2009-01-06 }}</ref>
[[Brisbane]], Australia - The South East Queensland Travel Survey collects travel data in the Greater Brisbane region and the neighbouring areas of [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]] and [[Sunshine Coast, Queensland|Sunshine Coast]]. The continuous survey commenced in 2003 and surveys around 6,000 households every two years.<ref>[http://www.transport.qld.gov.au/Home/Projects_and_initiatives/Projects/South_east_queensland_travel_survey/ Queensland Transport] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927153110/http://www.transport.qld.gov.au/Home/Projects_and_initiatives/Projects/South_east_queensland_travel_survey/ |date=2008-09-27 }}</ref>
[[Hobart]], Australia - The Greater Hobart Household Travel Survey collects information from 200 households each month.<ref>[http://www.transport.tas.gov.au/publications/greater_hobart_household_travel_survey Tasmanian Dept of Transport] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918214407/http://www.transport.tas.gov.au/publications/greater_hobart_household_travel_survey |date=2008-09-18 }}</ref>
[[London]], United Kingdom - The London Travel Demand Survey covers 8,000 households annually. Data is collected via face to face interviews.<ref>[http://www.tfl.gov.uk/corporate/projectsandschemes/5033.aspx Transport for London]</ref>
[[Sydney]], Australia - The continuous Household Travel Survey collects travel data annually for approximately 3,500 households in the Sydney Greater Metropolitan Region.<ref>[http://www.transport.nsw.gov.au/tdc/house-survey.html NSW Ministry of Transport] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720105033/http://transport.nsw.gov.au/tdc/house-survey.html |date=2008-07-20 }}</ref>
[[Washington, D.C.|Washington]], United States - The Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments conducted a 10,000 household survey in 2007.<ref>[http://www.mwcog.org/transportation/activities/hts/ MWCOG]</ref>
==Recent or continuous province/state-wide travel surveys== [[Southern Ontario]], the Transportation Tomorrow Survey<ref>[http://www.dmg.utoronto.ca/reports/ttsreports.html Data Management Group - University of Toronto] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913144459/http://www.dmg.utoronto.ca/reports/ttsreports.html |date=2009-09-13 }}</ref> was conducted in 2005-6 (two phases: September 2005 -> January 2006 and September 2006 -> February 2007). This is a repeat survey using essentially the same instrument as conducted in 1986, 1991, 1996, 2001 and most recently 2006 where 149,631 households comprise the final database. The survey was conducted using telephone interviews with an advance letter sent to households to solicit their participation.
==Recent or continuous country-wide travel surveys== [[Denmark]]'s most recent National Travel was initiated in 2006 and has been going on continuously since then. The interviews are conducted using the internet and telephone interviews.<ref>[http://www.modelcenter.transport.dtu.dk/english/tu]</ref>
[[Germany]] is conducting its National Travel Survey since 1994 on a yearly basis.<ref>[http://mobilitaetspanel.ifv.uni-karlsruhe.de/en The German Mobility Panel] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090911153315/http://mobilitaetspanel.ifv.uni-karlsruhe.de/en |date=2009-09-11 }}</ref> Each household member fills in a travel diary in which he records each trip made during the course of one week. Despite this yearly survey there is another non regular scheduled survey which is conducted again in 2008. 25,000 households are expected to participate.<ref>[http://www.travelsurveymethods.org/pdfs/newsletter09_08.pdf travelsurveymethods.org] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090920082123/http://www.travelsurveymethods.org/pdfs/newsletter09_08.pdf |date=2009-09-20 }}</ref>
[[Netherlands|The Netherlands]] National Travel Survey surveyed around 34,500 households in 2003. The survey has been conducted yearly since 1985, but with some changes in methodology. Survey forms are mailed out, with follow-up motivational phone calls.<ref>[http://www.swov.nl/uk/research/kennisbank/inhoud/90_gegevensbronnen/inhoud/ovg.htm Institute for Road Safety Research]</ref>
In [[New Zealand]] the Ministry of Transport annually surveys 4,600 households for a two-day period. Data is collected via face to face interviews.<ref>[http://www.transport.govt.nz/research/Pages/TravelSurvey.aspx/ NZ Ministry of Transport]</ref>
The [[United Kingdom]] Department for Transport conducts the National Travel Survey <ref>[http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/statistics/datatablespublications/personal/ UK Department for Transport] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015042603/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/statistics/datatablespublications/personal/ |date=2008-10-15 }}</ref>
The [[United States]] last conducted the National Household Travel Survey in 2009.<ref>[http://nhts.ornl.gov/introduction.shtml National Household Travel Survey]</ref>
[[South Africa]] conducted its first National Household Travel Survey in 2003. Successful interviews were held with 45,000 households.<ref>[http://www.arrivealive.co.za/document/household.pdf Dept of Transport, South Africa]</ref>
[[Sweden]]'s most recent National Travel Survey (RES) was conducted in 2006-06.<ref>[http://www.transport.gov.za/projects/nts/Default.html Sika Institute] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081112132337/http://www.transport.gov.za/projects/nts/Default.html |date=2008-11-12 }}</ref>
